body.p: An entity’s evaluation of whether a supplier’s substitution right is substantive is based on facts and circumstances at inception of the contract and shall exclude consideration of future events that, at inception of the contract, are not considered likely to occur. Examples of future events that, at inception of the contract, would not be considered likely to occur and, thus, should be excluded from the evaluation include:

li.p: an agreement by a future customer to pay an above market rate for use of the asset;
the introduction of new technology that is not substantially developed at inception of the contract;
a substantial difference between the customer’s use of the asset, or the performance of the asset, and the use or performance considered likely at inception of the contract; and
a substantial difference between the market price of the asset during the period of use, and the market price considered likely at inception of the contract.
